source.raw_text:
The Gladiator Dumbbell Deadlift is a rotational hip-hinge movement that builds posterior chain strength (glutes, hamstrings, back) and core stability, unlike standard deadlifts; it involves picking up one dumbbell with one hand while the other stays close to the back, creating anti-rotation and integrating hip extension with spinal stabilization, targeting forgotten muscles like the QL (quadratus lumborum) and deep core stabilizers for enhanced functional strength and injury resilience. [1, 2, 3]  
This video demonstrates the form for the Gladiator Dumbbell Deadlift: 
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Movers (Posterior Chain): Glutes, Hamstrings, Erector Spinae (lower back). 
• Stabilizers/Secondary Muscles: Obliques, Quadratus Lumborum (QL), Transverse Abdominis, Lats, Traps, Grip. 
• Legs: Quads (involved in knee extension during the lift). [1, 2, 4, 5, 6, 7]  

Movement Pattern 

1. Starting Position: Stand between two dumbbells, feet hip-width apart. 
2. Initiation: Reach across with one hand to grab the dumbbell on the opposite side, keeping the other dumbbell close to your back/pocket. 
3. The Hinge: Hinge at your hips (pushing them back) with a slight bend in the knees, maintaining a flat back. 
4. The Lift: Drive through your hips and squeeze your glutes to return to standing, keeping the dumbbell close to your body. 
5. Controlled Descent: Lower the weight slowly, focusing on the hip hinge and feeling the stretch in your hamstrings. 
6. Key Difference: Unlike a traditional deadlift, this is a rotational hinge, emphasizing anti-rotation and core control throughout the movement. [1, 2, 3, 8]
